Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Beta-decay Angular Correlation Measurements with Cold and Ultracold Neutrons
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds a collaborative research program involving two separate angular correlation measurements with neutrons. These measurements will enable us to extract fundamental information concerning the weak interaction which causes neutron decay, including the axial coupling constant of the nucleon. This coupling constant appears in a very wide variety of nuclear and particle physics contexts, from being a critical input to high precision calculations of the solar fusion rates, to being a target for higher precison lattice QCD calculations, to placing, together with the neutron lifetime, limits on the existence of new particle physics interactions.

The first experiment, UCNA, measures the beta-asymmetry, or the correlation between the neutron polarization and the decay beta-particle's momentum. UCNA is the first experiment to use ultracold neutrons, or neutrons with energies below about 300 neV that can be stored in material bottles, for this kind of measurement. Ultracold neutrons have advantages both for neutron polarimetry and neutron-generated backgrounds, key sources of systematic error in existing neutron angular correlation experiments. The UCNA experiment is currently operating, with one more run period planned at the neutron densities currently available at the Los Alamos ultracold neutron source. The targeted precision is below 0.4%, roughly a factor of 2 more precise than the current world average for the beta-asymmetry. The second experiment, Nab, uses an unpolarized beam of cold neutrons (with temperatures near 30K) to measure the electron-neutrino angular correlation, with a planned sensitivity at about the 0.1% level for the electron-neutrino correlation. This experiment should also be able to place important limits on extensions to the standard model of particle physics for scalar and
tensor couplings.

Key to the success of these experiments is the involvement of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral scholars. These young scientists will receive excellent training in experimental techniques, particle detectors, and data analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award 1307426, Collaborative Research: Beta-decay Angular Correlation Measurements with Cold and Ultracold Neutrons, set out to move forward three experiments in neutron beta decay.  The free neutron decays with a half-life of about 10 minutes into a proton, electron and an anti-neutrino, due to the weak nuclear force (called in this case the charged weak interaction, because it involves a change in the electric charge when the neutron transforms to a proton). Measurements of neutron decay can provide a precise characterization of the weak nuclear force acting on nucleons.  This force powers the sun and critically influences the primordial elemental abundances in the universe.  Because there is a very precise description of this force in our standard model of particle physics, we can also search for new forces and physics by performing high precision measurements of neutron decay, to look for deviations from the standard model predictions.

In order to completely characterize the weak nuclear force acting on nucleons, one needs to determine two (the vector and axial vector) coupling constants, requiring the measurement of two different observables in neutron decay.  In fact, two of the experiments supported by award 1307426 were designed to measure angular correlations between the decay products: UCNA, an experiment to measure the angular correlation between the initial neutron spin and the emitted electron momentum with polarized ultracold neutrons (UCN) and Nab, an experiment to measure the angular correlation between the decay electron momentum and the anti-neutrino momentum using cold neutron beams.  The final experiment, UCNtau, measures the neutron lifetime using polarized UCN. Over the course of this award we completed the analysis of the UCNA experiment, vetted the detector performance for Nab, and took first physics data for the UCNtau experiment.

The results of UCNA, with a relative uncertainty of 0.17% for the axial coupling constant,  and UCNtau, with a relative uncertainty of 0.09% for the lifetime, were disseminated to the physics community in 2017, and have resulted in the emergence of a consistent set of data from UCN experiments for the coupling constants from neutron decay. With the latest neutron measurements together with the superallowed beta decays, one can place limits at or above the sensitivity levels of the Large Hadron Collider at CERN for new physics coupling to the up and down quarks in the nucleon.  The Nab experiment is a next-generation experiment to measure angular correlations a factor of more than 6 better than UCNA, and is now being installed at the Spallation Neutron Source in Oak Ridge National Laboratory.  Nab will help push the sensitivity to new physics from neutron decay measurements well above the ultimate limits achieved by CERN.  Taken as a whole, the status of UCNA, UCNtau and Nab represent exciting progress in the field of fundamental symmetries, setting the stage to provide the definitive characterization of the charged weak interaction of the nucleon in ongoing or planned experiments on neutron decay.
